Not associated with liver cirrhosis
Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/litre

questions.text: True about Fibrolamellar carcinoma of Liver is all, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum AFP levels are usually > 1000 mg/liter

 

Option D:

 

Fibrolamellar carcinoma (FLC) of the liver is a rare variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) that has distinct clinical and pathological features.

 

Unlike typical hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar carcinoma is associated with normal or only mildly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels. AFP levels are generally not as markedly elevated as in other types of hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Unlike conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar carcinoma does not show a significant gender predilection. Both males and females are affected, and there is no clear male predominance.

 

Option B: Generally, fibrolamellar carcinoma is associated with a better prognosis compared to conventional hepatocellular carcinoma. It often occurs in younger individuals and is less likely to be associated with cirrhosis. Surgical resection is the primary treatment, and if the tumor is resected early, the prognosis can be relatively favorable.

 

Option C: Fibrolamellar carcinoma is characteristically not associated with liver cirrhosis. This is in contrast to conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, which is often linked to cirrhosis, especially in the setting of chronic liver diseases.

 

Educational objective:

 

AFP levels in fibrolamellar variant are generally not as markedly elevated as in other types of hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 873

Hepatitis B virus is an important risk factor
Often has a better prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B is an important risk factor

 

Option B:

 

Unlike conventional hepatocellular carcinoma, fibrolamellar carcinoma is not strongly associated with viral hepatitis, including hepatitis B.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fibrolamellar carcinoma can occur in both young males and females, typically in individuals without underlying liver disease or cirrhosis.

 

Option C: Fibrolamellar carcinoma is generally associated with a better prognosis compared to conventional hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D: Fibrolamellar carcinoma can present as a firm or hard tumor, but the classic description involves a large tumor with a central scar, giving a "stellate" or "wheel spoke" appearance on imaging.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 869

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic hepatitis B and cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain, unintentional weight loss, and fatigue. Imaging studies reveal a liver mass, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in adults. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Option C:

 

The most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in adults is hepatocellular carcinoma. HCC arises from hepatocytes and is closely associated with chronic liver diseases, particularly cirrhosis caused by viral hepatitis (hepatitis B and C), alcoholism, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

 

HCC is the most common type of primary liver cancer in adults and often arises in the setting of chronic liver disease, such as cirrhosis from hepatitis B or C, alcohol abuse, or nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of cancer that usually arises in the skin or tissues that line the internal organs, but it is not typically found in the liver.

 

Option B: Hepatoblastoma: Hepatoblastoma is a rare malignant liver tumor that is most common in children, not adults.

 

Option D. Hemangioma: Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign liver tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in adults and is often associated with chronic liver disease such as hepatitis B-induced cirrhosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 870

choices.text: Rise of AFP noted
Has stronger propensity to invade vascular channels
Chronic HBV has high rate of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.text: Which is not correct about hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More in females

 

Option A:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is more common in males than females. Therefore, the statement "More in females" is not correct.

 

Explanation

 

Option B: Elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) are commonly associated with HCC. AFP can be used as a tumor marker for HCC, and its elevation is often noted in individuals with this malignancy.

 

Option C: HCC has a strong propensity to invade vascular channels, leading to features such as portal vein invasion. This invasion is associated with a poorer prognosis.

 

Option D: Chronic infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a significant risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma. Chronic inflammation and cirrhosis associated with HBV infection contribute to the increased risk.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is more common in males than females.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 869

questions.text: A young woman Ms Shaano who is otherwise normal goes for an annual examination in a nursing home. Her blood investigations reveal hemoglobin is 15 gm/ dl, TLC is 7,000/mm3, ESR is 12 mm/hr. Her kidney and liver function tests are also normal. She undergoes a radiological scanning too. Dr. Sethi, the radiologist describes her findings to be normal except a mass in the right lobe of the liver. A biopsy is taken which confirms the diagnosis of a liver adenoma. Which of the following is likely to be associated with this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral contraceptives

 

Option C:

 

Liver adenomas are benign liver tumors commonly associated with oral contraceptive use in young women (usually 3-4th decade of life). They may resemble hepatocellular carcinoma. If they are subscapular, they can rupture, causing intra-abdominal haemorrhage leading to acute abdominal pain.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Hepatitis B may lead to hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option A: Polycythemia vera is associated with thrombosis of the hepatic veins.

 

Option D: Polyvinyl chloride, thorotrast (a contrast material) and arsenic are the risk factors for development of angio¬sarcoma of the liver. Immunohistochemical staining of these tumor cells is positive for the CD 31 cell marker.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver adenomas are benign tumors of the liver that are commonly associated with the use of oral contraceptives in young women.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 867

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with jaundice, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a mass lesion whose biopsy confirms the diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma. Which of the following locations is the most common site for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hilum

Option B:

Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy arising from the bile ducts, can occur at various locations along the biliary tree. The most common site of cholangiocarcinoma is the hilum, also known as perihilar or Klatskin tumors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cholangiocarcinoma can occur in the distal biliary tree, but perihilar tumors at the hilum are more common.

 

Option C: Cholangiocarcinoma can also arise within the intrahepatic biliary ducts but this is not the commonest site.

 

Option D: Cholangiocarcinoma can be multifocal, involving multiple sites along the biliary tree. However, the most common single site is the hilum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer arising from bile duct cells, with the most common site being the hilum of the liver, also known as perihilar or Klatskin tumors.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 871

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma of liver is caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clonorchis sinensis infection

 

Option D:

 

Clonorchis sinensis, a liver fluke, is a known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma (a malignancy arising from the bile ducts). Chronic infection with this parasite can lead to inflammation and damage to the bile ducts, increasing the risk of malignancy.

 

Explanation

 

Option A: Hepatitis B infection is a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, but it is not a well-established risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option B: Cirrhosis is more commonly associated with hepatocellular carcinoma rather than cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is primarily associated with lung and liver diseases, but it is not a well-established risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic infection with the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis is a known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma due to the chronic inflammation and damage it causes to the bile ducts.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 871

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with jaundice, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the bile duct. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of the most common bile duct tumor. Which histological type is most frequently associated with tumors of the bile duct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenocarcinoma

 

Option A:

 

The most common type of bile duct tumor is adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinoma arises from the glandular cells lining the bile ducts and is the predominant histological type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumors of the bile duct most commonly are adenocarcinomas, which originate from the glandular epithelial cells lining the bile ducts.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 871

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with new-onset jaundice and pruritus. The patient is concerned about the risk of developing liver cancer. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

 

Option B:

 

Risk factors for Cholangiocarcinoma (Mnemonic: All have alphabet ‘C’)

 

  • Primary sclerosing Cholangitis

  • Liver flukes like Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini

  • Cause of chronic biliary inflammation and injury (Choledo¬cholithiasis)

  • Contrat material: thorotrast

  • Chronic alcoholic liver disease

  • Congenital fibropolycystic diease (Choledochal cysts, Caroli’s disease)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Obesity: Increases risk for NAFLD and hepatocellular carcinoma, not specifically cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Salmonella carrier state: Associated with gallbladder carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. HBV infection: Strongly linked to hepatocellular carcinoma, not primarily to cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma is primary sclerosing cholangitis, which is associated with chronic inflammation and increased risk of malignancy in the bile ducts.

 

PSC is often associated with ulcerative colitis and leads to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of intra-and extrahepatic bile ducts. 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 871

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with painless jaundice, pruritus, and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a nodular mass obstructing the bile ducts at the hepatic hilum. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of a Klatskin tumor. Which of the following best describes this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nodular type of cholangiocarcinoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Cholangiocarcinomas are classified into intrahepatic and extrahepatic forms.

  • Eighty to 90% of the tumors are extrahepatic. The extrahepatic forms include perihilar tumors known as Klatskin tumors, which are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts forming the com­mon hepatic duct, and distal bile duct tumors.

  • Most extrahepatic CCAs appear as firm, gray nodules within the bile duct wall

  • Klatskin tumors generally have slower growth than other CCAs, show prominent fibrosis, and infrequently involve distal metastases.

 

A Klatskin tumor is a type of cholangiocarcinoma that occurs at the hepatic hilum where the right and left hepatic ducts join. It is often nodular and can obstruct the bile ducts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a distinct variant of hepatocellular carcinoma that typically affects younger individuals and has a characteristic appearance on imaging and histology, different from Klatskin tumors.

 

Option C: Gall bladder carcinoma:  Gall bladder carcinoma typically arises in the gall bladder itself and not in the bile ducts, hence it is not a Klatskin tumor.

 

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a primary liver cancer that originates from hepatocytes. A Klatskin tumor, however, arises from the biliary epithelium at the confluence of the left and right hepatic bile ducts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Klatskin tumors are nodular cholangiocarcinomas located at the hepatic hilum and are known for causing biliary obstruction.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/871
